reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s “value is a product of many quasi-independent factors” model, which is a meaningful support for the ‘eutopia is fragile’ theme, but not the sole pillar of the overall thesis (the essay also offers many non-model-based examples of moral catastrophe and a long Section 3 argument that many plausible moral views are ‘fussy’ for other reasons). So centrality is moderate. The critique does provide real pressure: multiplicativity and (quasi-)independence do substantial work in generating extreme rarity and ‘one flaw ruins everything,’ and pointing to additive/threshold/substitutable structures plus cross-factor correlation would weaken that particular inference. However it doesn’t decisively refute the broader claim that mostly-great futures are hard, since fragility/fussiness could still arise under many non-multiplicative moral structures, and the original text already frames the multiplicative story as a toy/illustrative model rather than a necessary theorem. Most claims in the critique are broadly correct (multiplicativity is a strong assumption; independence is doubtful; many evaluative frameworks allow substitution), though it somewhat overstates how much the paper’s “core intuition” depends on that model. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little to no filler.
title: The product of factors model lacks empirical grounding
